</p><p class="MsoNormal">On 29<sup>th</sup> July 2019 small-scale farmers began
protesting, continuously through days and nights, with a sit-in in front of the
district‚Äôs planning administration (Satara Collector Office) against the
expansion of Karad Airport in Maharashtra State, India.[1] The farmers who
started the sit-in (Thiyya Aandola) announced they would continue their protest
until the government meets their demands and cancels the expansion project.[2] They
submitted details of their concerns to the Satara Collector and the CMO (Chief
Minister‚Äôs Office). This agitation is the latest in the ongoing resistance of
farmers opposing the airport expansion for more than 8 years, since 2011. The
protests take place under the aegis of the socio-political organization Shramik
Mukti Dal.</p>

<p class="MsoNormal">The farmers claim that the expansion will not help the
development of the district, but on the contrary, will lead to their
impoverishment: For expansion of an existing airstrip into a fully-fledged
airport next to the city of Karad, fertile and irrigated farm-land will be
acquired. Vinayak Shinde, spokesperson of the affected villagers and activist
of Shramik Mukti Dal, says that 1,335.46 hectares of farmland cultivated with
an irrigation-system are under threat. Critical infrastructure for the
irrigation system is located on the land to be acquired. Shinde said: Residents
of the villages of Warunji, Kese, Munde, Padali, Gote and Supane have worked to
develop this irrigation scheme for more than 50 years, explains Shinde, saying ‚ÄúIf
the land acquisition is carried out this will be a huge loss for about 25,000
people who depend upon this agriculture.[1]</p>

<p class="MsoNormal">On 30<sup>th</sup> August, after the villagers had
maintained their protest for 33 days, they were joined by a member of the Bhairavanathi
cooperative irrigation project.[3] The villagers also staged a protest at the
airport gate. They demanded information about airport operations including the
number of planes and helicopters using the facility since 2011 and whether
nearby hills would pose risks to aircraft safety if the expansion goes ahead.[4]
</p>

<p class="MsoNormal">Already in 2011, Bharat Patankar, President of Shramik Mukti
Dal pointed out, that the expansion of the Karad Airport violates the national
resettlement and rehabilitation policy, which prohibits acquisition of
irrigated farmland. Karad Airport lies just 2 kilometers to the west of the
city of Karad. According to the Airport Authority of India, developments of
airports should be at least 15 km away from a city.[1]</p>

<p class="MsoNormal">Announcement of plans for Karad Airport expansion in 2011
triggered a major protest, on 6th July about 1,000 farmers = protested against
land acquisition, marching from the airport to the sub-divisional office (SDO)
where they submitted a memorandum and demanded a meeting with then Chief
Minister of Maharashtra, Prithviraj Chavan, to discuss their grievances. The demonstrators
were accompanied by farmer leader Ashok Thorat who said: ‚ÄúNo one from Karad has
ever demanded expansion of the airport. There are no industries in Karad, so commercial
air services were never introduced on this airport since inception.‚Äù He said
Karad Airport was only used ‚Äúonce in a while‚Äù, by ministers and other public representatives.[5]</p>

<p class="MsoNormal">In July 2012 The Hindu reported that more than 4,000 farmers
from the region were opposing Karad Airport expansion. Farmers warned of
agitation and Ashok Thorat said ‚Äúthe farmers are serious about not giving up
the land‚Äù.[6] In December 2012 Karad Airport expansion was raised in the
Maharashtra Legislative Assembly and a protest was held in front of the airport.[7]</p>

<p class="MsoNormal">Karad Airport also lies close to the Munde electricity
station in Karad, which is the main station of electricity transfer from the Koyna
hydroelectricity project. Affected villagers are concerned that tall
electricity towers surrounding the area of the planned expansion could be a
risk factor for aviation safety.</p>

<p class="MsoNormal">Affected villagers have also challenged the economic viability
of the airport expansion. A Government of Maharashtra report raised concerns
regarding commercial viability due to Karad Airport‚Äôs close proximity to the
existing Kolhapur Airport, a mere 70 kilometers away. Also, the Maharashtra Airport
Development Company, established by the Maharashtra state government to
construct several airports, proposed withdrawal of the Karad Airport expansion
project because of doubts over its commercial viability.[1]</p>

<p class="MsoNormal">On 15<sup>th</sup> September 2019, after 50 days and nights,
farmers ended their sit-in protest again Karad Airport expansion. The farmers
maintain that the airport expansion project is illegal.[8]</p>

<p></p>

other_types:
The state of California, USA has set high goals to shift its energy system towards a more sustainable one based on renewable energy (RE) resources. In 2015, it harvested more solar electricity than all other 49 U.S.A. states combined. Before 2009, no solar projects were permitted on public land in California. By 2015, there were already 29 solar project permissions in the South-West of the U.S.A.. Developing large-scale solar projects in the state of California has become increasingly challenging as new federal regulations seek to decrease the environmental footprint and impact of especially large-scale projects. On the other hand, the Obama administration gave the development of renewable energy sources priority by pledging to generate 20 gigawatt of power by 2020, which equals powering six million homes. [1]

 

 

The project

The Ivanpah Solar Electric Generating System (ISEGS) is located in California‚Äôs Mojave Desert and was at the time of construction (2012) the largest concentrating solar power (CSP) plant in the USA. The power plant is based just below California‚Äôs Clark Mountain, close to the state line of Primm, Nevada. [2] The ISEGS plant occupies approximately 3,500 acres (ca. 1,416 ha) of federal land administered by the US Bureau of Land Management (BML). Upon completion, the project aimed to double the total solar electricity output generated in the USA. In 2012, the Ivanpah SEGS project was therefore awarded the ‚ÄòCSP Project of the year‚Äô by the organization Solar Power Generation USA. [3] The project is meant to be an ‚Äúenvironmentally responsible project‚Äù [3], as it aims to contribute to the reduction of CO2 emission of around 400,000 tons on an annual basis. The technological system of CSP employed by BSE is considered to be one of the most land-efficient RE technologies. The heliostat layout is flexible and can thus be built around natural contours avoiding sensible vegetation and areas. [3] Due to water scarcity the Ivanpah SEGS uses a closed-loop air-cooling system allowing the plant to use 90% less water than equivalent power plants utilizing wet-cooling. [3] The director and vice president of the developing company BrightSource Energy stated the Ivanpah Solar power plant will be an important step to get California closer to its goal of generating 33% of its electricity by renewable energy (RE) resources by 2020. [2]

 

Timeline

In 2006, the developer BrightSource Energy (BSE) applied for a pre-qualification with the Department of Energy (DOE) Loan Guarantee program. [2] After that, BSE submitted the first application for certification (AFC) to build a solar power plant in 2007. However, since then, environmental groups in California objected the project due to the possibility of disturbances of the tortoise habitat in the Ivanpah valley (see below). Nevertheless, the construction of the Ivanpah SEGS had its break ground date in October 2010 and was expected to deliver electricity to the two utility companies PG&E and Southern California Edison by 2013. [3] This goal was missed and electricity generation started in 2014. [2]

 

 

Environmental impacts and related conflicts

There are two main ecological dangers expressed by environmental groups that are directly related to the Ivanpah solar projects. The first environmental impact is on wildlife ‚Äì more specifically on birds, insects and the desert tortoise, whereas the second is on water usage. Further, there is a controversy on the unions involved in the project.

 

1.     Impact on Birds and flying insects.

According to an article published on the platform Renewable Energy World there are some measurable and quantifiable impacts from the solar power plant on insects and birds. Birds physically strike all kinds of human-made infrastructure such as transmission lines, buildings or wind turbines. In general, most of these strikes have the nature of a physical collisions causing birds‚Äô deaths, or (mortal) injuries. In the case of the ISEGS project, there are collisions between birds and the power tower‚Äôs heliostats, but also damages caused by ‚Äúelevated concentrations of solar flux‚Äù [4], which are a ‚Äònew‚Äô form of human-made environmental impact. Solar flux is the reflected, concentrated sunlight close to the towers. Birds are suffering ‚Äòfeather singeing‚Äô which impairs their flying ability and can thus lead to their death. [4] According to the conservation group ‚ÄòCenter for Biological Diversity‚Äô, the ISEGS project could kill up to 28,380 birds annually. This number is an extrapolation from a study conducted by an environmental organization, which is opposing the project. [5] Among the affected species were hummingbirds, warblers, doves, swallows and sparrows. [4] Another study published in IEEE Spectrum mentions data gained by monitoring from October 2013 to October 2014 claims a range of 693 to 3,504 birds from 83 different species and an additional 32 dead bats. [5]

 

Some birds (nighthawks, yellow warblers [6]) of that region are feasting on insects (e.g. ‚Äúcaterpillars, grasshoppers, dragonflies, beetles, bees and wasps‚Äù [6]). These small insects are turned immediately into ash when entering a solar flux concentrated light beam.

 

In general, the closer the birds get to the solar towers, the higher their risk is of singeing respectively dying. In order to develop an effective deterrent, scientists of the Smithsonean Institution‚Äôs forensic lab analyzed which types of birds were affected. After the bird‚Äôs identification, a possible technological mitigation strategy is using the birds‚Äô fear of predation.

In total there are three mitigation strategies consisting of three technologies. Firstly, ‚Äòbio-acoustic deterrence‚Äô([4][5]), secondly, ‚Äònonlethal avian respiratory irritant‚Äô and thirdly, equipping towers with ‚Äòanti-perching spikes‚Äô [6].

 

 

2.     Desert tortoise

 

The environmental organization ‚ÄòBasin and Range Watch‚Äô  states on their webpage, that Ivanpah valley is of excellent quality as a desert tortoise habitat. In 1994, the so-called Desert Tortoise (Mojave Desert) Recovery Plan was established distinguishing between six ‚Äúdesignated evolutionary significant units‚Äù of which the habiting Northeastern Mojave tortoises are the genetically most distinct ones. When the recovery plan was conducted the Ivanpah valley showed to have the highest known tortoise density with 200 to 250 animals per square kilometer. In 2011 the recovery plan was revised showing that large areas of the Ivanpah area do show ‚Äúhigh potential‚Äù to support the desert tortoises. Scientists‚Äô findings demonstrated that conservation measures are required in order to ensure the survival viability of the population.  [7]

 

In surveys, environmentalists have found 25 desert tortoises around the project‚Äôs land as stated in an article found on a blog of the New York Times [8]. The environmental groups stated that BSE‚Äôs first reaction in reducing the total electricity producing capacity of the ISEGS power plant was a step into the right direction. Anyhow, it did not dissolve the environmentalist‚Äôs concerns, since BSE would not do anything to protect the desert tortoises by just reducing the project‚Äôs size and reducing energy generated. ‚ÄúThis reconfiguration is pretty minimal from what we‚Äôve seen, and it hasn‚Äôt really addressed the core issues on the impact on desert tortoise and rare plants‚Äù [8] said the Californian representative for Defenders of Wildlife, the environmental organization in charge. However, the company stated that significant changes were already made to the project, alluding a decrease of the overall output of the power plant from 440 to 392 MW. [8] The company BSE also hired an environmental consultant to review the new design. [8]

Later, fences around the plant‚Äôs territory were installed in order to protect the desert tortoises. The fences causes roadrunners (type of non-flying bird) to get trapped in the fences‚Äô mesh and becoming easy prey for coyotes. In an further step Ivanpah‚Äôs environmental manager installed ‚Äòroad runner exits‚Äô into the fence (holes about 8 inches in diameter and 18 inches above ground .[6]

 

 

3.     Rare plant species

 

According to the environmental organization ‚ÄòBasin and Range Watch‚Äô the Ivanpah valley in which the ISEGS is to be located. The valley within the Mojave Desert is valued by scientists to be of ‚Äúunparalleled pristine quality among deserts‚Äù and also to be one of the ‚Äúworld‚Äôs last functional ecosystems‚Äù. [7] In total twelve rare plant species were documented on the ISEGS‚Äôs project site such as the ‚ÄúMojave Milkweed, White-margined Penstom, and Desert Pincushion‚Äù [7]. The California Energy Commission considered five of these plant species to be significant for the California Environmental Quality Act and concluded that a substantial portion of the their habitat would be threatened. The California Native Plant Society that a simple translocation of the plants would not be sufficient and that there is no known mitigation method compensating for the loss of rare plant habitat. Consequently, the only suitable mitigation strategy is not constructing in sensible plant‚Äôs habitat. [7]

 

 

4.     Water controversy

 

The increasing need for scarce fresh water sources is a key issue and concern for the development of California‚Äôs renewable energy sector [11]. The Ivanpah project would use an estimated 25 million gallons of water per year mainly in order to wash its mirrors. Utilizing a wet-cooled solar through system would imply drawing 705 million gallons of water in the Mojave desert ‚Äì an area of very scant rainfall. There is a general legal fight taking place in California where via a legal bill was being prepared that should allow the usage of  drinking water when harvesting RE power in California. Terry O‚ÄôBrien, the California Energy Commission deputy director commented on this with the following: ‚ÄúBy allowing projects to use fresh water, the bill would remove any incentives that developers have to use technologies that minimize water use,‚Äù. [9] Ivanpah‚Äôs developer consequently intends to swap to the solar tower technology in order to rid the problem of water scarcity in the Mojave desert. Solar towers can be cooled with an air-cooling system needing to a great extent less water. In general, the downside from a business-perspective of using dry-cooling systems is that costs are added and the overall efficiency is reduced, which leads to less profit. However, BSE claims that deploying dry-cooling system in the Ivanpah project does not lead to a ‚Äúprohibitive decline in power output‚Äù.  [9]

 

5.     Tribal resistance

 

Phillip Smith is a Chemehuevi, an elder of the Colorado River Indian Tribe and Ron Van Fleet (Fort Mohave Indian Tribe) state about the cultural relevance of the plant‚Äôs site to their tribes. They tell that their ancestors have come to the ‚Äúaltars‚Äù (stones on the site of the Ivanpah plant) to ‚Äúworship the divine and admire the Mojave Desert.‚Äù [10] In September 2010, about 20 protesters came to the sacred site to protect the 5.6-square-mile stretch. P. Smith stated that animals such as ‚Äúdesert tortoises, bighorn sheep, mountain lions, haws, snakes, and many sensitive medical plants‚Äù are ‚Äúgetting squeezed out‚Äù of the area and further that they ‚Äì the local tribes are ‚Äútheir protectors‚Äù. [10] He further told that the company BrightSource Energy would destroy their home to profit from the cheap electricity of the sun stating that the project is about ‚Äúfast money. It‚Äôs all fast money.‚Äù And that this goes against the living space of the indigenous tribes and the animals that have been living in the same area of the project‚Äôs site. P. Smith reminds that there were times with to cities such as Los Angeles and Las Vegas and that these ancient sites have been being of importance to the tribal cultures. [10]

 

The reply of a BSE‚Äôs spokesman was that they had not heard of the American Indians‚Äô concerns until then, adding that they (BSE) ‚Äúshare their passion for the desert‚Äù [10] and that they are confident that the approach they are taking ‚Äúis the right approach from an environmental perspective‚Äù.[10]

 

6.     Labor union Controversy (California wide and applies specifically to the Ivanpah case)

 

The Union group California Unions for Reliable Energy raised no complaint when they were informed of BSE‚Äôs intention to build a bigger power plant than the competing companies. To give an example: another company called ‚ÄòAusra‚Äô was before deluged by a union group on environmental issues.

The Californian union group ‚ÄòCalifornia Union for Reliable Energy‚Äô even urged regulators to speed up the approval process in case of the BSE project. The difference between BSE and Ausra is that BSE had before pledged to hire labor-friendly contractors. The Ausra company even accused labor unions to make abuse of environmental laws in order to gain a labor agreement. Some developers contend that they are forced to sign agreements pledging to utilize union labor, if they refuse ‚Äúthey can count on the union group to demand costly environmental studies and deliver hostile testimony at public hearings‚Äù [11]. Instead if they commit to make use of union labor, they would not let the environmental objections materialize. Californian energy commissioner Jeffrey Byron comments:  ‚Äúthis does stress the limits of credibility [of the union‚Äôs environmental concerns] to some extent‚Äù [11]

 

Californian unionist lawyers negotiate both labor agreements and also participate in the environmental reviews of the projects. The main question that arises from this fused conflict of interests is if the future green sustainable energy system will be based on a service economy with low-paid employees installing solar technology or higher paid union labor.

Consequently, companies such as Spinaker Energy and Stirling Energy Systems cannot enter a labor agreement on a solar project in California. Some environmental groups being worried about that these labor union tactics could cause a backlash in transitioning to a renewable energy system. Others again, confirm that California‚Äôs unions show a effectiveness at receiving extracting concessions that finally aid the environment.  Anyhow, the ‚Äúblue[union]-green[environmentalists] alliances‚Äù are showing strains. [11]

 

Outcome & Status Quo:

The project was constructed and has been producing electricity since 2014.

In 2010, the project there was an amendment in size of the project. It was scaled down from 440 MW to 392 MW gross energy generation [8] mainly because of disturbing the habitat of the imperiled desert tortoise that must be relocated and further avoiding the disturbance of the area of rare plants. Initially, the project was intended to take up 4,000 acres of land (1,619 ha). This number was shrunk by 12%, according to a The New York Times article [8] However, the same article states that BSE managed to sidestep the water and labor controversies by utilizing a water-saving air-cooling system, respectively contracting union labor (see above).

The construction of the project was temporarily halted on April 15th 2011 for impacting desert tortoises by the US Bureau of Land Management (BML) due to endangering desert tortoises. [12] Thereafter, the wildlife organization US Fish and Wildlife Service found on 10th June 2010 that the project did not jeopardize the endangered desert tortoise anymore the BML lifted the construction hold/ban. [13] In response to the concerns over the project‚Äôs impacts on wildlife animals and their habitat, the developer BSE installed fences in order to keep wildlife (especially desert tortoises) out of the project‚Äôs area.

In order to mitigate the birds‚Äô problem the above mentioned two measurements were taken: 1st ‚ÄòBio-acoustic deterrence systems‚Äô, 2nd ‚Äòanti-perching spikes‚Äô to hinder birds from getting into the light beams. A third measurement is the ‚Äònonlethal avian respiratory irritant‚Äô was discussed but not being installed. Whatsoever, one can say that the Ivanpah project is taking a leading role when it comes to testing the effectiveness of bird deterrents in large scale solar energy projects.

The deputy chief of the environmental organization Fish and Wildlife Service‚Äôs migratory bird program states that they would like to transport the learnings on deterrents to other solar energy projects around the world. [6]

other_types: National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act provides no recognition of indigenous people‚Äôs right to consultation or to access their traditional lands and resources. The authority to manage resource use ultimately lies in the hands of the national park warden, who grants the right of conditional use to local communities at his discretion. No mechanisms for co-management of park governance. Sherpa leaders are involved in promoting ICCA management. The Sherpa community and identity remains strong within the Khumbu region. Many traditional land use and resource management practices continue to this day and have at times even been encouraged by the government and park authorities. Areas of contention still exist, such as the recognition of Sherpa indigenous rights, and the ecological strain placed on the environment by unrestricted tourist growth.

other_types:
In January 2020, TotalEnergies and Apache announced a significant oil discovery in Block 58 offshore Suriname. The find was commensurate with discoveries in the nearby Stabroek block offshore Guyana and sparked hopes for an oil bonanza in the country [1]. The oil companies continued exploring for oil with new wells and have since announced 5 successful drills, the latest in February 2022 [2]. Two further exploratory wells have failed to find commercial reserves in the block [3]. For now there is no clear development plan for the reserves, and the Final Investment Decision has been pushed forward to 2023 [4].


The Suriname economy has been historically linked to extractive sectors. Between the 17th and 19th century, the country's economy was initially focused on cocoa, sugar and cotton slave plantations under dutch colonial rule. In the 20th century, bauxite and aluminium became dominant sectors of the economy [5]. Currently, gold mining represents 75% of exports, with an important presence of artisanal small scale mining. Finally, the oil sector is becoming more important and now represents 10% of exports. Both the gold and oil sector are controlled through the national oil company Staatsolie which mostly developed onshore oil exploitations in Saramacca district until 2016. That year, after significant discoveries in the same oil basin in nearby Guyana, offshore exploration licences were put on tender to international oil companies, subject to participation rights for Staatsolie [6].


Local environmental activist Erlan Sleur, chairman of Probios, opposes the extraction of offshore oil and advocates to keep the oil in the ground. The arguments defend that an oil spill would spell a death sentence to the mangroves along the country‚Äôs coast. According to the organisation, the mangroves are the best defence against sea level rise, as they will grow higher with the ocean waters protecting the shoreline. Furthermore, they oppose seismic exploration test as they will disturb the ocean wildlife [7].


Erlan Sleur regrets there is not much opposition locally. People are convinced by the promises that the oil sector will bring rapid economic development and lift them out of poverty. However, he thinks that corruption and mismanagement will land the profits with the multinationals and the national cliques, and leave nothing for the Surinamese [7]. In a study on the oil deals and their financing by international development banks, the german environmental justice organisation urgewald, indeed finds that ‚Äúultra low royalty (6.5%) and tax rates for oil investments remain, while tax rates for non-oil sectors and citizens increase, with the heaviest burden falling on the poorest people‚Äù. They criticise the involvement of the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank in supporting the establishment of international oil companies in Suriname at the expense of expanding the country‚Äôs crippling debt and the devastation of the climate [8].


In compensation for leaving the oil in the ground, the local conservation organisation Probios demands rich countries pay Suriname for protecting nature [7]. In what initially would seem like a move towards the environmental justice demands from local organisations, TotalEnergies struck a deal with Suriname‚Äôs government in November 2021 to preserve the country‚Äôs forest. Under the agreement, the company would pay $50m in exchange for an unspecified amount of carbon credits. But this is not what local organisations demand, TotalEnergies wants to drill for oil and pay the crumps for forest protection without clear evidence demonstrating any emissions avoidance. BankTrack defends that such carbon credits schemes ‚Äúreduce the incredible diversity of the planet‚Äôs forests, grasslands and wetlands to a commodity that will be traded, and in the process triggering a massive new resource grab from Indigenous Peoples, peasants and local communities, mainly in the global South.‚Äù BankTrack denounces the deal as ‚Äúthe greenwashing of oil Block 58‚Äù and reminds that no new fossil fuel projects are compatible with limiting global warming to 1.5¬∫C. The international organisation demands that banks and insurers stop supporting the expansion of the fossil fuel industry in general, and TotalEnergies‚Äô Block 58 in particular [9].


The tragic global environmental injustice is patent in this deal with the devil: ‚Äúas rich countries fail to deliver on their obligations to reduce emissions and provide climate and mitigation finance, a country that will be impacted severely by the consequences of climate change now finds itself in bed with an oil giant.‚Äù [9]

En Francais ci-dessous --- The issues concerning Mbeubeuss landfill are multiple and complex to solve. Located 27km away from the capital, Mbeubeuss is a means of subsistence for one of the poorest populations in Dakar suburbs while the open-air landfill causes high air and soil contamination in the Malika District where more than 17,000 people live. The waste picker community is largely formed by young people unable to find a job. Mbeubeuss landfill represents their last chance to make a living. About 4,000 informal waste pickers vigorously defend their source of revenue even though it highly puts their health and lives at risk. They are a marginalized and discriminated group among the Senegalese society but they have organized in the Bokk Diom Association in the late 1990s when the government tried to remove them and later were granted formal recognition. Bokk Diom continues fighting against their discrimination, and for their recognition, cohesion, and social rights.

There has been an ongoing discussion about the closure of Mbeubeuss landfill for many years. At stake is the generation of private profits from the management of waste. Foreign investment interests, mainly coordinated under the World Bank programs, have been proposing and influencing the Senegalese government. Already in 2005, a report from the Energy Sector Management Assistance Program (part of the World Bank) proposed the privatization of Mbeubeuss‚Äô waste for the creation of a gas capture technology to generate electricity. The funds would have been provided through the UNFCCC‚Äôs Clean Development Mechanism but the project never materialized. By 2009, the closure of the Mbeubeuss landfill became conditionality for the relocation of the 3,000 households near Pikine, being displaced for the construction of a highway between Dakar and Diamniadio. The chosen relocation area was just two kilometers away from Mbeubeuss. The Senegalese government‚Äôs creditors (mainly the International Development Association, part of the World Bank Group) for the highway project were pressuring for the landfill closure. The World Bank was proposing to open a new site that would have only generated 300 jobs and where salaries would have been lower than the current earned revenues at Mbeubess.

The waste pickers defended their self-employment and mobilized through Bokk Diom and with the help of ENDA to oppose the project. As a result, the situation of the landfill remains still the same, open and managed by the informal waste pickers. Besides the World Bank and its associated programs, also other development agencies, such as the Canadian agency IDRC advocated for the closure of Mbeubeuss for sanitarian and environmental reasons. The agency funded the project ‚ÄúPure‚Äù from 2006 to 2011 during which it monitored the social, health, and environmental impacts of the landfill on the living communities, the farmers and vegetable growers from Malika but also Diamalaye and Njagoo neighborhoods. These impacts should not be undermined, but the waste pickers fight for bottom-up mitigation solutions for the landfill impacts which takes into consideration their perspectives and needs, instead of a managerial, imposed perspective whose aim would be to foster private and foreign profits. They fiercely defend their source of livelihood. The involvement of international and foreign institutions is not necessarily going against the waste pickers‚Äô will. For instance, Bokk Diom has set up a school for the children of the dump with financial help from European organizations (French Agence Francaise du Developpement, the Luxembourg Agency for Development and the Belgian Ministry for Cooperation). The waste pickers also obtained funds from the United Nations Development Program to construct a medical center and the International Labor Organization has trained youth from the dump in other professions such as carpenter or baker. Security issues remain recurrent in the landfill and put at risk the lives of more than 400 waste pickers living inside the site.

The most recent tragedies happened in December 2016 when a massive fire - the so-far largest ever recorded at the landfill - killed three people. This also caused economic damage to the community as many waste pickers lost tons of recycled waste. Another fire happened in March 2017. After these tragedies, the public authorities committed to proposing a new study on the possibilities of the future of the landfill, expected by June 2017. In February 2018, another massive fire broke out at the Mbeubeuss landfill, destroying stored recycled waste, shelters, and most notably, the facilities of a small recycling business run by one of the founders of Bokk Diom, who started as a waste picker in the 1970s and now employed 75 people. This induced the association to stronger mobilize for on-site improvements at Mbeubeuss and also a crowdfunding campaign was started.

As of 2019/20, Mbeubeuss landfill is frequented by 4,000 waste pickers that are members of Bokk Diom and pay an annual union fee and even more who are not, and extends over an area of 175 hectares. The situation at the landfill was recently described by media as ‚Äúout of control‚Äù and ‚Äúan ecological and sanitary bomb‚Äù. While the waste picker community continues to face dangerous working conditions, insecurity, and a lack of social and health protection, also locals suffer from the adverse impacts of uncontrolled dumping. In December 2019, a group of nearby residents called ‚ÄòMbeubeuss Dafa Doy‚Äô (from the Malika, Yeumbeul Nord et Sud, Keur Massar, and Tivaouane Peul communities) staged protests and criticized the misinformation by and inaction of public authorities, as the dump closure was already promised in 2012. The group demanded the relocation of the site and announced that, if necessary, they will proceed with the protests and block garbage trucks from entering the site.

In 2019, the organization WIEGO (Women in Informal Employment ‚Äì Globalizing and Organizng) together with the the ILO launched a project to improve conditions for the waste pickers of Mbeubeuss and strengthen their organizing in a cooperative. The cooperation was started with a two-day workshop that brought together informal waste pickers, leaders of Bokk Diom, and several institutions involved in waste management. WIEGO, as part of its Focal Cities initiative, has been working with informal workers across the city and among others initiated a project to improve the position of informal women waste pickers, including elderly, who are unlikely to find formal employment. They provided training in cooperative management and the strengthening of women‚Äôs worker identity. It supported the women‚Äôs cooperative ‚ÄòAVER-B‚Äô that brings together street vendors, domestic workers, waste pickers, and informal food manufacturers in marketing their products. Bokk Diom, which to 60 percent of women, now also has a Women‚Äôs Recycling Committee that aims to strengthen women‚Äôs rights at Mbeubeuss landfill.

Most recently, new plans to modernize, rehabilitate and enclose the Mbeubeuss landfill were pushed forward by international institutions. In 2020, the Senegalese government received a new $US 125 loan from the International Development Association (IDA), a World Bank subsidiary, to modernize waste management in several cities. According to the plans, a public-private partnership should be established in Mbeubeuss to establish a waste treatment and disposal system in several phases. This would, first, include emergency measures to ensure safety at the site and prevent the entering of unauthorized persons. Later on, the site should become remodeled and optimized, including the installing of a leachate treatment system and a recycling center, in which former waste pickers would become employed.

The year 2020 brought the so far most visible mobilization of waste pickers in Dakar, as waste pickers of the Bokk Diom association held a silent demonstration march on the Global Waste Pickers Day, 1st of march, to commemorate the struggle of informal waste pickers around the globe. They also held a press conference in which they presented a memorandum with a counter-proposal to the new Mbeubeuss landfill modernization project. This, most notably, concerns a higher number of waste pickers to become part of the new landfill project and the creation of further opportunities to include waste pickers in municipal waste management.


***

Mbeubeuss est un moyen de subsistance pour les recycleurs informels, une des populations les plus pauvres de la banlieue de Dakar, alors que qu‚Äôen m√™me temps la d√©charge en plein air provoque une forte contamination de l'air et du sol dans le district de Malika o√π vivent plus de 17 000 personnes. Ils ont alors √©t√© formellement reconnus par le gouvernement. Bokk Diom continue de lutter contre leur discrimination, pour leur reconnaissance, leur coh√©sion et leurs droits sociaux. La discussion de la fermeture de Mbeubeuss se poursuit depuis plusieurs ann√©es. Les investissements √©trangers, principalement coordonn√©s par des programmes d√©pendant de la Banque Mondiale, proposent et influencent le gouvernement s√©n√©galais. Ce qui int√©resse ces investissements ce sont les profits qui seraient g√©n√©r√©s par une gestion priv√©e des d√©chets. D√©j√† en 2005, un rapport du Programme d'Aide √† la Gestion du Secteur de l'Energie (membre de la Banque mondiale) a propos√© la privatisation des d√©chets de Mbeubeuss pour la capture de gaz afin de produire de l'√©lectricit√©. Les financements auraient √©t√© fournis par le M√©canisme de D√©veloppement Propre de la CCNUCC. Mais le projet ne s'est jamais concr√©tis√©. En 2009, la fermeture de la d√©charge de Mbeubeuss √©tait une condition pour la relocalisation des 3 000 m√©nages pr√®s de Pikine, d√©plac√©s pour la construction d'une autoroute entre Dakar et Diamniadio. En effet, la zone choisie pour la r√©installation de ces familles √©tait √† 2 kilom√®tres de la d√©charge. Les cr√©anciers du gouvernement s√©n√©galais (principalement l'Association Internationale de D√©veloppement, groupe membre de la Banque Mondiale) pour le projet routier pressaient la fermeture du site Mbeubeuss. En contrepartie, la Banque Mondiale proposait d'ouvrir un nouveau site qui n'aurait g√©n√©r√© que 300 emplois et dont les salaires auraient √©t√© inf√©rieurs aux revenus actuellement gagn√©s par les recycleurs. Bokk Diom s‚Äôest mobilis√©, avec l'aide d'ENDA pour s'opposer au projet. Les recycleurs ont vigoureusement d√©fendu leur travail ind√©pendant. En cons√©quence, la situation de la d√©charge demeure la m√™me, g√©r√©e par les r√©cup√©rateurs de d√©chets informels. Outre la Banque Mondiale et ses programmes associ√©s, d'autres agences de d√©veloppement, comme l'agence canadienne CRDI / CRDI, plaident en faveur de la fermeture de Mbeubeuss pour des raisons sanitaires et environnementales. L'agence a financ√© le projet ¬´Pure¬ª de 2006 √† 2011, au cours duquel elle a surveill√© les impacts sociaux, sanitaires et environnementaux de la d√©charge sur les communaut√©s avoisinantes, sur les √©levages de porc et la production de l√©gumes √† Malika et dans les quartiers de Diamalaye et Njagoo. Ces impacts ne devraient pas √™tre ignor√©s, mais les recycleurs se battent pour d√©fender des solutions d'att√©nuation de ces impacts qui tiennent compte de leurs points de vue et de leurs besoins, contre une perspective impos√©e par le haut dont l'objectif serait avant tout de favoriser le profit d‚Äôacteurs priv√©s et √©trangers. L‚Äôimplication des Institutions Internationales et √©trang√®res ne va pas n√©cessairement contre la volont√© des recycleurs, au contraire certains acteurs collaborent avec la communaut√© de Mbeubeuss. Les r√©cup√©rateurs de d√©chets ont √©galement obtenu des fonds de la part du Programme des Nations Unies pour le D√©veloppement afin de construire un centre m√©dical et l'Organisation Internationale du Travail a form√© les jeunes de la d√©charge √† d'autres professions comme la boulangerie ou la menuiserie. <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom:12.0pt"><b><span style="font-size:11.0pt;
font-family:"Arial",sans-serif;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
color:black;mso-fareast-language:ES-TRAD">Ejido el Baj√≠o: Defensa del
territorio, ejidatarios masacrados y desacato empresarial a fallo judicial</span></b><span style="font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Arial",sans-serif;mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";color:black;mso-fareast-language:ES-TRAD"> </span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom:12.0pt"><span style="font-size:11.0pt;
font-family:"Arial",sans-serif;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
color:black;mso-fareast-language:ES-TRAD">En junio de 2014, ocurri√≥ un hecho
in√©dito en M√©xico. El Tribunal Unitario Agrario n√∫mero 28 con sede en la ciudad
de Hermosillo, capital del estado fronterizo de Sonora, fall√≥ a favor de la
demanda de 67 ejidatarias y ejidatarios de ‚ÄúEl Baj√≠o‚Äù, un ejido enclavado
en el desierto, totalmente en el municipio de Puerto Pe√±asco y alevosamente
registrado en el municipio de Caborca, basti√≥n de la minera Penmont. La
sentencia judicial obliga a la minera Penmont, subsidiaria de  Frsnillo
PLC del consorcio Industrias Pe√±oles, a devolver el oro extra√≠do ilicitamente,
a restituir a cabalidad las condiciones ecol√≥gicas en las estaba el territorio
antes de la construcci√≥n ilegal de la mina a cielo abierto pues la minera
destruy√≥ cerros, horad√≥ la superficie y aniquil√≥ flora y fauna. De no poder
hacer la restituci√≥n , deber√° pagar el equivalente en dinero. </span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom:12.0pt"><span style="font-size:11.0pt;
font-family:"Arial",sans-serif;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
color:black;mso-fareast-language:ES-TRAD">El Ejido El Baj√≠o cuenta con una
extensi√≥n de 21,038 hect√°reas de las cuales, 3000 se han perdido porque la
minera Penmont abri√≥ la mina a cielo abierto. Destruyendo todo. </span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom:12.0pt"><span style="font-size:11.0pt;
font-family:"Arial",sans-serif;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
color:black;mso-fareast-language:ES-TRAD">El Primer Tribunal Colegiado en
Materias Penal y Administrativa del Quinto Circuito, ratific√≥ el 28 de
Noviembre de 2014 el fallo del Tribunal Unitario Agrario 28 de Sonora. La 
instancia judicial superior reconoc√≠a la propiedad social de la tierra, bajo
la forma ejidal, de la comunidad campesina e ilegitimaba el despojo de la
minera. Las y los ejidatarios hab√≠an demandado a uno de los tres consorcios
mineros m√°s poderosos no solo de M√©xico sino de Am√©rica Latina, encabezado por
el patriarca de la miner√≠a Alberto Baill√©res Gonz√°lez. </span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom:12.0pt"><span style="font-size:11.0pt;
font-family:"Arial",sans-serif;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
color:black;mso-fareast-language:ES-TRAD">Hasta este momento, el gigante minero
se encuentra en desacato, no cumpli√≥ con el fallo de las  instancias
judiciales e inici√≥ una contraofensiva, centrada en la criminalizaci√≥n y la
persecuci√≥n contra la comunidad ejidataria. El 12 de Octubre de 2014 ocho
ejidatarios fueron levantados por militares, les sembraron armas. Enviaron a
Pedro Francisco Santiago a un penal de alta seguridad en Tepic, Nayarit, acus√°ndolo
de poseer una escopeta que le fue sembrada. El  3 de septiembre de 2017 fue
secuestrado por un comando armado el Presidente del comisariado ejidal, Jos√© de
Jes√∫s Robledo Cruz. El 24 de octubre de 2017 fueron levantados, torturados
y  amenazados 12 ejidatarios. El 12 de febrero de 2018 fueron asesinados
Nohem√≠ Elizabeth L√≥pez Guti√©rrez y Ra√∫l Ibarra de la Paz. El 29 de abril de
2021, Jos√© de Jes√∫s Robledo Cruz y Mar√≠a de Jes√∫s G√≥mez Vega fueron
acribillados. Ellas y ellos representaban a la comunidad ejidal y fueron
activas y activos defensores de la restituci√≥n de sus tierras.  </span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom:12.0pt"><span style="font-size:11.0pt;
font-family:"Arial",sans-serif;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
color:black;mso-fareast-language:ES-TRAD">La resoluci√≥n judicial contra el
poderoso consorcio Industrias Pe√±oles toc√≥ dos pilares de la acumulaci√≥n por
despojo (Roux, 2008) que se vive en el pa√≠s desde hace tres d√©cadas: las
ganancias ilimitadas a partir de la devastaci√≥n ambiental y la impunidad
con la que ha operado.  </span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom:12.0pt"><span style="font-size:11.0pt;
font-family:"Arial",sans-serif;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
color:black;mso-fareast-language:ES-TRAD">A la fecha, la comunidad ejidataria
del desierto sonorense despliega diversos mecanismos de resistencia para
recuperar el territorio al que les rob√≥ la minera de la familia Baill√©res y
hacer cumplir el fallo judicial. Las mujeres han jugado un papel
preponderante en el sostenimiento de la organizaci√≥n de la resistencia y han
mantenido la autonom√≠a de la asamblea ejidal, m√°xima instancia de decisi√≥n del
n√∫cleo agrario.  </span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom:12.0pt"><span style="font-size:11.0pt;
font-family:"Arial",sans-serif;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
color:black;mso-fareast-language:ES-TRAD">Las dimensiones del despojo
territorial de los consorcios mineros de los patriarcas
empresariales Carlos Slim Hel√∫, Germ√°n Larrea Mota-Velasco y Alberto
Baill√©res Gonz√°lez, que se convirtieron en los hombres m√°s ricos de Am√©rica
Latina,implican la posesi√≥n de poco m√°s de 3 millones de
hect√°reas de territorio mexicano, similar al tama√±o de estados
de la rep√∫blica como Puebla o Yucat√°n. El acaparamiento mediante el despojo a
los pueblos de sus tierras, les permite el saqueo de metales y la especulaci√≥n
con la renta de la tierra, lo que explica que el 70 por ciento, o
m√°s, de los ingresos de sus conglomerados provenga de la
extracci√≥n minera.  </span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom:12.0pt"><span style="font-size:11.0pt;
font-family:"Arial",sans-serif;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
color:black;mso-fareast-language:ES-TRAD">Industrias Pe√±oles tiene la concesi√≥n
de tierras m√°s grande en M√©xico, casi 2 millones de hect√°reas. Ocupa el 1er
lugar como productor de plata en M√©xico y es el principal exportador de
este metal. Su subsiduaria Fresnillo, Plc., se jacta de tener los costos de
producci√≥n m√°s bajos en la curva de costos de la plata (Industrias Pe√±oles,
2014). Este es el poderoso consorcio minero que la comunidad ejidataria
sonorense ha enfrentado durante m√°s de una d√©cada mediante movilizaciones y una
batalla jur√≠dica que a√∫n no concluye. El gran consorcio transnacional perdi√≥
jur√≠dicamente frente a una de las comunidades ejidales m√°s pobres del
pa√≠s. Las y los ejidatarios de El Baj√≠o lograron  sacar a la minera
Penmont de su territorio luego de una movilizaci√≥n en Palacio Nacional en 2020,
solicitando al presidente Andr√©s Manuel L√≥pez Obrador que retirara a la fuerza
publica ‚ÄúGuardia Nacional‚Äù de sus tierras. La minera Penmont cont√≥, antes
de este hecho, con el apoyo de las fuerzas de seguridad estatal y federal para
impedir que los ejidatarios  recuperaran las 21,038 hect√°reas
restituidas por el fallo agrario. </span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom:12.0pt"><span style="font-size:11.0pt;
font-family:"Arial",sans-serif;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
color:black;mso-fareast-language:ES-TRAD">A la fecha deben hacer guardias en su
propio territorio para cuidar que no vuelvan a ser tomadas por la minera que
los acosa con grupos criminales. La determinaci√≥n de esta comunidad por la
defensa de la tierra los ha llevado a una lucha en varios frentes. Junto con la
movilizaci√≥n hasta la Ciudad de M√©xico y las guardias permanentes han buscado
hacer visible el conflicto que cre√≥ el consorcio Pe√±oles (Ver documental
‚ÄúTolvanera‚Äù </span><a href="https://ejidoelbajio.mx/2021/07/16/tolvanera-documental-sobre-la-resistencia-del-ejido-el-bajio-se-proyecta-en-el-festival-internacional-de-cine-de-durango" target="_blank"><span style="font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Arial",sans-serif;
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";color:#1155CC;mso-fareast-language:
ES-TRAD">https://ejidoelbajio.mx/2021/07/16/tolvanera-documental-sobre-la-resistencia-del-ejido-el-bajio-se-proyecta-en-el-festival-internacional-de-cine-de-durango</span></a><span style="font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Arial",sans-serif;mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";color:black;mso-fareast-language:ES-TRAD">/). La
Asamblea Ejidal acord√≥ dedicar este territorio a la conservaci√≥n de la unidad
ecol√≥gica del desierto de la que es parte el ejido El Baj√≠o. A fin de buscar la
conservaci√≥n de la flora y fauna ha solicitado certificar su territorio como
‚Äú√Årea Natural Protegida de manera Voluntaria‚Äù. √âsta, tambi√©n, es una
medida para proteger el agua que se encuentran a m√°s de 210 metros de
profundidad. Tambi√©n han emprendido la b√∫squeda de la desincorporaci√≥n de
El Bajio al municipio de Caborca y pasar a formar parte del Municipio
de Puerto Pe√±asco. </span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom:12.0pt"><span style="font-size:11.0pt;
font-family:"Arial",sans-serif;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
color:black;mso-fareast-language:ES-TRAD">En los √∫ltimos 10 a√±os, aumentaron
significativamente los conflictos en Am√©rica Latina y el Caribe entre los
consorcios mineros ‚Äì ‚Äúque conciben los territorios como espacios vac√≠os y
disponibles‚Äù (T√©llez y S√°nchez Salazar, 2018) y las comunidades que los
ocupan.  El triunfo judicial de la comunidad campesina de El 
Ejido El Baj√≠o, en el noroeste de Sonora, puede convertirse en un caso
emblem√°tico de la tensi√≥n entre la ofensiva de las megamineras y el
aparato estatal y la defensa del territorio, de una comunidad en particular,
que est√° en sinton√≠a con decenas o cientos de comunidades en toda la regi√≥n
latinoamericana. </span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom:12.0pt"><span style="font-size:11.0pt;
font-family:"Arial",sans-serif;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
color:black;mso-fareast-language:ES-TRAD">En el caso de la comunidad ejidataria
de El Baj√≠o, se evidencia lo que Maristella Svampa caracteriza
como la abierta conflictividad en los territorios extractivos, cuando
expresa que ‚Äú(‚Ä¶) fueron numerosos los conflictos socioambientales y
territoriales que lograron salir del encapsulamiento local y adquirieron una
visibilidad nacional‚Äù. Explica asimismo que, a partir de 2010, las
comunidades ind√≠genas y campesinas latinoamericanas lograron el reconocimiento
de sus derechos colectivos, territoriales y ambientales como parte de los cambios
jur√≠dicos democr√°ticos gubernamentales. En M√©xico, en 2011 se incorpor√≥ a la
Constituci√≥n nacional la perspectiva de los derechos humanos. Estos
avances en la ‚Äúfrontera de los derechos‚Äù (Svampa, 2019) puede ser una de las
razones que explican el fallo del Tribunal Unitario Agrario en 2014 a favor de
la comunidad ejidataria sonorense. </span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom:12.0pt"><span style="font-size:11.0pt;
font-family:"Arial",sans-serif;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
color:black;mso-fareast-language:ES-TRAD">Por otro lado, algunos millonarios
como los Luksic de Chile o mexicanos como Slim, Baill√©res y Larrea
Mota-Velasco <i>lograron</i> extender sus negocios
extractivistas a trav√©s de un proceso de despojo m√∫ltiple, en el que el
estado respald√≥ y promovi√≥ el proceso de monopolizaci√≥n de la tierra, al
otorgarles la concesi√≥n de los territorios para extraer minerales. Estos
personajes no habr√≠an acumulado esa riqueza personal y empresarial
exorbitante sin el apoyo del aparato estatal que construy√≥ el andamiaje legal
para impulsar y reconfigurar dicha acumulaci√≥n de capital. Entonces, en el
curso de tres d√©cadas, en la regi√≥n se configuraron dos tendencias jur√≠dicas
contradictorias: las reformas jur√≠dico estructurales que crearon leyes que
protegen y validan la acumulaci√≥n por despojo de los consorcios
transnacionalizados y, en contraste, el paradigma de los derechos humanos y las
legislaciones garantistas que validan los derechos colectivos, culturales
y territoriales de los pueblos ind√≠genas y campesinos (Pel√°ez, 2015). Esta es
la disputa por los bienes comunes en Am√©rica Latina y el
Caribe.   </span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom:12.0pt"><span style="font-size:11.0pt;
font-family:"Arial",sans-serif;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
color:black;mso-fareast-language:ES-TRAD">No obstante la imbricaci√≥n entre
estas burgues√≠as de la regi√≥n y diversos dispositivos legales y policiales para
garantizar su acumulaci√≥n incesante de ganancias en el sector minero, a
trav√©s de los mecanismos de la acumulaci√≥n por despojo, la resistencia de las
comunidades campesinas e ind√≠genas o la oposici√≥n comunitaria como las de Conga
y T√≠a Mar√≠a en Per√∫, actualmente suspendidas, al igual que Pascua Lama en
Argentina, los efectos del derrame de la minera Vale en Brasil y los
crecientes movimientos de resistencia en diversas regiones de M√©xico, definen
la din√°mica de conflictividad socio ambiental y territorial en toda la
regi√≥n. </span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Arial",sans-serif;
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";color:black;background:white;
mso-fareast-language:ES-TRAD">La asimetr√≠a entre las y los ejidatarios
sonorenses que enfrentaron a Industrias Pe√±oles frente al despojo provocado por
las minas Dipolos y La Herradura de la subsidiaria Penmont, ha implicado
una batalla de m√°s de una d√©cada y a√∫n no se define.</span><span style="font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
mso-fareast-language:ES-TRAD"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom:12.0pt"><span style="font-size:11.0pt;
font-family:"Arial",sans-serif;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
color:black;mso-fareast-language:ES-TRAD"> </span></p>

<span style="font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Arial",sans-serif;mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";color:black;mso-ansi-language:ES-MX;mso-fareast-language:
ES-TRAD;mso-bidi-language:AR-SA">Ejido El Baj√≠o </span><span style="font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Calibri",sans-serif;mso-ascii-theme-font:
minor-latin;mso-fareast-font-family:Calibri;mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-latin;
mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";

La Raffineria di Roma nasce per opera dei conti Miani nei primi anni ‚Äò50 nei pressi di Trastevere. Nel 1965 viene rilevata dalla Total Fina Italia S.p.A. e spostata nell'attuale sede di Ponte Galeria, a ovest di Roma, tra l‚ÄôAurelia, il Grande Raccordo Anulare e la Roma Civitavecchia [1].

Quest‚Äôarea, Malagrotta, √® soggetta ad una forte pressione ambientale, infatti, nel raggio di 50 km¬≤ sono presenti anche la nota discarica di rifiuti urbani, un inceneritore di rifiuti ospedalieri e farmaci scaduti dotato di un sistema per il recupero energetico (termovalizzatore), depositi di idrocarburi e cave per inerti [2]. La raffineria √® stata per molti anni l‚Äôunico polo di lavorazione e distribuzione di prodotti petroliferi dell‚ÄôItalia centrale.

Fino al 2010 la quota di maggioranza della raffineria era di propriet√† della Total Fina [3]. A seguito della joint venture tra Total e Erg, la nascente TotalErg diviene proprietaria al cento per cento dell'impianto [4]. Alla fine del 2012, viste le difficolt√† del settore, la TotalErg decide di cessare l'attivit√† di raffinazione mantenendo in funzione solamente il polo logistico per lo stoccaggio e la distribuzione di carburanti gi√† lavorati [5].

Decisione presa anche a causa della forte concorrenza che le societ√† asiatiche e mediorientali esercitano nel settore petrolifero. Infatti, grazie al minor costo dell'energia, a una legislazione pi√π permissiva per quanto riguarda le normative ambientali, ai vantaggi fiscali di cui spesso queste societ√† possono godere e anche a un costo del lavoro nettamente pi√π basso, il mercato viene inondato dal petrolio di queste zone, facendo diventare sconveniente la produzione di idrocarburi in Italia, come nel resto d'Europa [6].

A partire da questa situazione e visto l'andamento altalenante dei mercati, l'Unione Petrolifera stimava, nella primavera del 2012, che in Italia fossero a rischio oltre 7500 posti di lavoro, considerando che ogni raffineria, indotto compreso, occupava in media 1500 persone [7].

Quanto questa stima fosse realistica, lo ha dimostrato il fatto che, oltre alla struttura romana, negli ultimi anni sono stati chiusi anche gli impianti di Falconara, di propriet√† dell'Api, e quello di Gela, di propriet√† dell'ENI [5].

Nel caso specifico della Raffineria di Roma, a partire dal giugno del 2012 si sono susseguite varie iniziative e manifestazioni di protesta da parte dei lavoratori nei confronti dell'azienda per evitare licenziamenti di massa. La TotalErg S.p.A., per√≤, non aveva presentato tempestivamente un vero e proprio piano occupazionale, pur avendo annunciato la trasformazione della raffineria in un polo logistico per lo stoccaggio, e quindi alla fine dello stesso anno centinaia di persone si ritrovarono senza lavoro [7][8].

Nel contempo, all'interno del dibattito pubblico, si √® ricominciato a parlare anche della pericolosit√† del sito contro il quale, per lungo tempo, gli ambientalisti e i movimenti civici avevano dato battaglia. Per anni, infatti, le ciminiere, a due passi dalla discarica di Roma, sono state il simbolo dell'aspetto pi√π distruttivo di un modello di sviluppo altamente impattante sia per l‚Äôambiente che per la salute [7].

√à per questo motivo che a partire dagli anni ‚Äô90 furono incoraggiati diversi studi epidemiologici ‚Äì che tuttora continuano ad essere effettuati con cadenza periodica ‚Äì vista la presenza nella stessa area di diversi impianti industriali e il conseguente aumento della preoccupazione dei residenti riguardo i possibili rischi per la loro salute. I risultati delle indagini (i pi√π recenti sono datati aprile 2013) hanno dimostrato che ci sono stati eccessi di mortalit√† per varie tipologie tumorali ‚Äì tra le quali spiccano quelle ai polmoni e alla vescica oltre che decessi causati da tumori celebrali e mieloma multiplo ‚Äì tra i lavoratori della raffineria che si sono succeduti negli anni [2]. Dagli stessi studi epidemiologici non √®, invece, emersa una diretta correlazione tra l'aumento di malattie tumorali tra la popolazione che vive nelle vicinanze della raffineria e la raffineria stessa [2].

In tempi pi√π recenti, la Raffineria di Roma √® tornata alla ribalta delle cronache per dei furti di gasolio avvenuti nel febbraio del 2015, in cui sono stati forati i tubi della condotta dell'impianto, procurando un'enorme perdita di carburante (oltre 5mila litri) nel canale delle Vignole e nel terreno adiacente alla zona della raffineria, compromettendo irreparabilmente l'ecosistema ambientale dell'intera area [9].

A seguito di questo avvenimento, la Prefettura di Roma, con Decreto prot. n. 185764 del 2 luglio 2015, ha approvato il Piano di Emergenza Esterna (PEE) per la Raffineria di Roma visti i rilevanti rischi di incidente [10].

Nonostante il conflitto, almeno dal punto di vista della produzione, sembrava essere chiuso, nell'Agosto del 2017 una novit√† ha riacceso l'allarme sulla raffineria. Il primo Agosto 2017 infatti √® stata avvitata la procedura di verifica di assoggetabilit√† ambientale presentata dalla raffineria di Roma S.p.A. per le modifiche impiantistiche presso il deposito di Pantano di Grano per l‚Äôimplementazione di un sistema di ricezione, stoccaggio ed esportazione del greggio estratto dai giacimenti Tempa Rossa. Nello specifico "il progetto prevede la possibilit√† di garantire il transito settimanale di circa 22.950 m3

di grezzo provenienti dal centro trattamento olii di Corleto di Perticara in Basilicata. Il trasferimento del grezzo avverr√† tramite autobotti e isocontainers, per un numero stimato massimo giornaliero di 170 mezzi aventi capacit√† di 30 m3, che saranno caricati fino ad

un massimo di 27 m3. Dal Deposito di Pantano di

Grano, il grezzo sar√† quindi inviato, attraverso il reparto costiero di Fiumicino su nave a mezzo delle infrastrutture esistenti [11][12].

other_types:
There are three operating uranium mines in Australia -Ranger in Kakadu National Park in Northern Territory; Olympic Dam in South Australia; and Beverley with Four Mile in South Australia.  Ranger is situated within the perimeter of the World Heritage listed Kakadu National Park (Kakadu).  Kakadu has two other rich uranium deposits yet to be developed - Jabiluka and Koongarra.

Ranger was developed against the wishes of local traditional owners - the Mirrar people.  Senior Traditional Owner Toby Gangale, opposed plans for uranium exploration and mining on his country in the 1970s.  His opposition, along with that of other local Aboriginal people, was overruled by the Federal Government when it legislated for the development of the Ranger Uranium Mine in 1976.  Ranger commenced operations in 1980, the mine is now run by Energy Resources Australia (ERA) which is majority owned by Rio Tinto. 

Since the early 1980s, yellowcake from Mirarr land has been sent to fuel nuclear reactors in Japan, Europe and elsewhere. By 2019 Ranger uranium mine is now coming to the end of its life. Mining has concluded and minimal processing of stockpiled ore continues as the company contemplates the enormous rehabilitation task.

ERA announced the closure and rehabilitation of the entire site by 2021.  In December 2014 ERA called for public comment on its environmental impact statement for a massive new ‚ÄòRanger 3 Deeps‚Äô underground mine. The Australian Conservation Foundation (ACF, Sweeney 2014) responded that the proposed mining technique was untested in monsoonal tropical areas and risked the rehabilitation of the site.  ACF cited the 200+ leaks, spills, accidents and license breaches at Ranger Uranium Mine to date and the negative impacts on local (Indigenous) communities living downstream as well as the environmentally and culturally significance of the environment: ‚ÄòIt is home to the world's richest breeding grounds for migratory tropical water birds, majestic waterfalls, vast wetlands teeming with wildlife, Indigenous rock art sites and over 50,000 years of living tradition and cultural practice‚Äô.

After the Fukushima accident, the traditional landowners were worried also by the impact of the activity on their land has on others. The possibility of uranium from Mirarr land being incorporated into a nuclear weapon or present at the site of a nuclear accident is therefore of enormous concern to Mirarr. Despite assurances from successive Federal Governments that Australian uranium is only sold for nuclear power, the fact remains that is impossible to guarantee Australian uranium does not end up in nuclear weapons. In April 2011, following the earthquake, tsunami and subsequent nuclear disaster in Japan, Yvonne Margarula wrote to UN Secretary-General Ban ki-Moon and expressed her sorrow at the impacts radiation is having on the lives of Japanese people. She noted that, ‚Äòit is likely that the radiation problems at Fukushima are, at least in part, fuelled by uranium derived from our traditional lands. This makes us feel very sad.‚Äô  (1).

Leaving aside the damage that the extracted uranium has done elsewhere, the local rehabilitation costs amount to hundreds of millions of dollars.  After the price collapse following the Fukushima nuclear crisis, times in the uranium trade were difficult. Coupled with a mandated end to commercial operations by early 2021, Rio Tinto has accepted the era of mining has now been replaced by the need for rehabilitation.

But the challenge for Energy Resources of Australia and Rio Tinto, who own and operate the mine, is not simple. It is to ensure radioactive and contaminated mine tailings are "physically isolated from the environment for at least 10,000 years [and that] any contaminants arising from the tailings will not result in any detrimental environmental impacts for at least 10,000 years."(2).

El 13 de junio de 2023, la comunidad de Escol√°sticas, Pedro Escobedo en Quer√©taro, vivi√≥ una confrontaci√≥n entre pobladores y tres agencias policiales (dos municipales y una estatal) que deriv√≥ en once personas detenidas [1]. Esto ocurri√≥ mientras pobladores, con presencia importante de mujeres y ni√±os, se manifestaban por la aprehensi√≥n contra tres personas por el presunto delito despojo de un predio en la localidad de El Sabino [2].

La Fiscal√≠a argument√≥ una detenci√≥n legal mientras los pobladores se√±alaron el uso indebido del aparato penal para favorecer a un particular [3]. El origen del conflicto es la definici√≥n de propiedad de un predio en cuyo interior se encuentran manantiales de competencia federal y √°rboles sabinos milenarios, un √°rea de importante valor ecol√≥gico [4]. Las hect√°reas se encuentran en disputa legal [5] entre la propiedad comunal datada de 1936 y una serie de compra ventas privadas se√±aladas como irregulares por no contar con la autorizaci√≥n de la asamblea ejidal. La disputa tiene precedentes de conflictos, incluyendo amenazas y agresiones por parte de distintos particulares hacia la comunidad ejidal en 1936, 1968, 1973 y 1996. Quien se ostenta como el m√°s reciente propietario es quien interpuso la denuncia penal motivo de las detenciones. Investigaciones period√≠sticas revelaron que mantiene una estrecha relaci√≥n de favorecimiento indebido con el gobierno local [6].

Grupos ambientalistas como Vocer@s de la Madre Tierra han acompa√±ado a la comunidad de Escol√°sticas en la protecci√≥n y defensa de su tierra com√∫n. En abril de 2023 realizaron se√±alamientos sobre la construcci√≥n de un muro cercando el √°rea de manantiales conocida como "Los Sabinos" y  la alteraci√≥n de √°rboles end√©micos, los cuales califican como susceptibles de protecci√≥n federal por su valor como patrimonio natural y seguridad h√≠drica. Tambi√©n detectaron venta privada de pipas de agua proveniente de los manatiales comunitarios [7].

Durante el operativo, las 11 personas detenidas, entre ellas un menor de 17 a√±os, sufrieron fuertes lesiones, permanecieron temporalmente desaparecidas y fueron localizadas en centros penitenciarios solo despu√©s de la intervenci√≥n judicial. La Defensor√≠a de los Derechos Humanos de Quer√©taro (DDHQ), ante quien se interpuso queja formal, no inici√≥ queja de oficio ni medidas cautelares pese a que su personal estuvo en el lugar de los hechos [8].

Luego de que redes nacionales, actores internacionales y organizaciones locales emitieron pronunciamientos, adem√°s de la presi√≥n social y recursos de amparo, el 20 de junio, 9 personas fueron liberadas bajo amenaza y a√∫n en condici√≥n de penalmente acusadas [9].

Igual que en otros casos de defensa del territorio, en Escol√°sticas se report√≥ estigmatizaci√≥n de la protesta por parte de las autoridades [10] intimidaci√≥n a las personas defensoras [11] y criminalizaci√≥n. Este es el tercer caso de represi√≥n a la defensa del agua en el estado de Quer√©taro en 2022 y 2023 [12].

other_types:
The case is about the environmental group Milieudefensie/Friends of the Earth suing the Royal Dutch Shell for failing to play its part in the fight against climate change and thereby breaching its duty of care under Dutch law and human rights obligations.

Established in 1971, Milieudefensie is the Netherland‚Äôs most influential climate organization. Since 1972, it has been a member of Friends of the Earth International, the largest grassroots environmental network on an international level [1]. Shell, previously known as Royal Dutch Shell [2], is an Anglo-Dutch multinational and one of the largest oil and gas companies worldwide and in consequence one of the biggest corporate producers of greenhouse gases [3].

In 2019, Mileudefensie together with other NGOs and the signatures of more than 17.000 citizens, started a lawsuit against Shell arguing that Shell has an obligation to contribute to the prevention of climate change on basis of the duty of care under the unwritten standard of the Dutch Civil Code, Book 6 Section 162 and the Paris Climate Agreement of 2015. In line with these legal foundations, they demanded that Shell reduce its emissions by 45% by 2030 - compared to the 2019 level - and use its great influence to provide consumers with more sustainable choices. According to Milieudefensie, Shell had known the dangerous effects of the company‚Äôs emissions for decades and failed to take appropriate action up to the present time [4].

Shell defended itself by giving mainly two arguments: First, they argued that cutting out further emissions would not have any effect because those emissions would be replaced by other companies due to the EU Emissions Trading System (ETS). Second, Shell argued that there was no legal basis for the company to be sued for its emissions and that the plaintiff‚Äôs arguments were too general in order to fall within the scope of the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) [5].

On May 26 in 2021, The Hague District Court ruled that Shell had to reduce its emissions by 45% by 2030 across emissions from its own operations and effects of the company‚Äôs produced oil. According to the court, this decision was made on the basis of the duty of care under the unwritten standard of the Dutch Civil Code and the Paris climate goals [6].

As of today, Shell has not taken any action to further reduce its emissions in line with the court's decision. It should also be mentioned that the company moved their headquarters from the Netherlands to the UK, even though the company denies any relation of the relocation to the court‚Äôs judgment but explains it mainly with the 15% dividend tax that the Dutch government puts on big multinationals [7]. In April 2022, Milieudefensie sent a letter to the company's board of directors asking for urgent action. Shell, for its part, appealed against the court's decision in June 2022, and it remains to be seen what the outcome of this conflict will be [5]. However, it raises the broader question of whether private companies can be held responsible for taking appropriate action on climate change and liable for failing to do so.

Shanxi Antai Group (Â±±Ë•øÂÆâÊ≥∞ÈõÜÂõ¢, Antai) is a publicly listed company (600408.SH) located at Yi‚Äôan Town of Jiexiu City in Jinzhong, Shanxi Province, China. Yi‚Äôan Town, home to a population of 59,043 as of 2017[1], is known for its coke production. Jiexiu City is also considered China‚Äôs largest metallurgical coke production and export base, with Antai as one of China‚Äôs six largest merchant coke suppliers.[1], [2] Antai‚Äôs subsidiary Shanxi Hong‚Äôan Coking Technology Co., Td. (Â±±Ë•øÂÆèÂÆâÁÑ¶ÂåñÁßëÊäÄÊúâÈôêÂÖ¨Âè∏) was founded in 2004 and specializes in the production and sales of coke and coking by-products. According to the disclosure by the International Finance Corporation (IFC) which provided a USD 70 million loan to the coking subsidiary of Antai in 2004, the company‚Äôs coking plant was expected to produce 1 million tons of coke per year when completed.[3], [4]

Antai is a key target under state monitoring and control in terms of environmental pollution (ÂõΩÊéßÈáçÁÇπÊ±°Êüì‰ºÅ‰∏ö). According to All-China Environment Federation (ACEF, ‰∏≠ÂçéÁéØ‰øùËÅîÂêà‰ºö), the data published by Automatic Pollutant Monitoring Platform for Corporates under Intense State Monitoring and Control (ÂõΩÊéßÈáçÁÇπÊ±°ÊüìÊ∫êËá™Âä®ÁõëÊéßÂπ≥Âè∞) by MEE indicated that the percentage of days that Antai‚Äôs coking plant‚Äôs air pollutants including sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxides exceeded the standard was as high as 93% between June 2015 and October 2016 after China‚Äôs new environmental protection law came into effect.[5] Antai‚Äôs subsidiary Hong‚Äôan Coking Technology was also notified and publicized by the Environmental Protection Bureau of Shanxi Province for its excessive emissions for two consecutive quarters in August 2015.[6] In 2016, ACEF filed a public interest civil litigation on the ground of air pollution responsibility dispute at the Intermediate People's Court of Jinzhong City, Shanxi Province (Â±±Ë•øÊôã‰∏≠‰∏≠Á∫ß‰∫∫Ê∞ëÊ≥ïÈô¢) and requested the court to order Antai‚Äôs coking plant to bear the cost of atmospheric environmental restoration cost of CNY 2,098,553.[5], [7]

The Intermediate People's Court of Jinzhong City, Shanxi Province accepted the case on January 19, 2017. Considering that Shanxi Antai Group had completed the desulfurization technology upgrade at that time and the pollutant emission level had met the standard, the company and ACEF voluntarily reached a mediation agreement with the support of the court in organizing the mediation in March 2018. As a result, Shanxi Antai Group agreed to pay for CNY 537,800 for atmospheric environment restoration costs, which will be used for the environmental resource restoration in Jinzhong City. Besides, the plaintiff‚Äôs attorney‚Äôs agency fees, travel expenses, and case acceptance fees incurred in this case are all borne by the company. Antai also made an apology publicly for the pollution incident, committed to a sustainable development strategy, and welcomed the general public to monitor its environmental governance efforts. [8], [9] This public interest litigation case, along with two other cases filed by ACEF on the issue of air pollution, was awarded among the ‚ÄúTop 10 Public Interest Litigation in China‚Äù in 2016.[10]

During the public interest litigation case investigation and even after the mediation, there were still complaints regarding the coking plant‚Äôs pollution by local residents on China‚Äôs social media Weibo and reported by journalists between 2017 and 2020. A journalist from Judicial Weekly (Ê≥ïÊ≤ªÂë®Âàä) documented the pollution after conducting a site visit in Jiexiu in August 2017.[6] The site visit covered two different coking plants in Jiexiu, after which the journalist filed a complaint to the Environmental Protection Bureau of Jiexiu City and received no response. The journalist wrote an article in which he questioned the environmental governance and monitoring capacity of the local government of Jiexiu, especially considering that the central government‚Äôs environmental inspection had started in 2015.[6]

In March 2018, the local residents at Liujiazhai Village (ÂàòÂÆ∂ÂØ®Êùë) in Jiexiu near the coking plant of Antai‚Äôs subsidiary Hong‚Äôan Coking Technology filed a complaint to the Secretary of Shanxi Province Party Committee (Â±±Ë•øÁúÅÂßî‰π¶ËÆ∞) via the People.com (‰∫∫Ê∞ëÁΩë) website.[11] The Shanxi Provincial Committee of Social Affairs and Public Opinion Office (Â±±Ë•øÁúÅÂßîÁ§æÊÉÖÊ∞ëÊÑèÂäûÂÖ¨ÂÆ§) provided a response to the residents‚Äô complaint. The response indicated that the Jiexiu City Environmental Protection Bureau requested Shanxi Yuhang Environmental Monitoring Co., Ltd. (Â±±Ë•øÊ¶ÜËà™ÁéØÂ¢ÉÁõëÊµãÊúâÈôêÂÖ¨Âè∏) to monitor the environmental performance of the Hong‚Äôan coking plant, and the monitoring report showed that the plant‚Äôs emissions mostly met the standard. On the other hand, Jiexiu City‚Äôs municipality government issued the "Implementation Plan for the Relocation and Resettlement of Residents within the Sanitation Protection Area of ‚Äã‚ÄãJiexiu City" („Ää‰ªã‰ºëÂ∏ÇÂç´ÁîüÈò≤Êä§Ë∑ùÁ¶ªÂÜÖÂ±ÖÊ∞ëÊê¨ËøÅÂÆâÁΩÆÂÆûÊñΩÊñπÊ°à„Äã) and the "Responsibility Decomposition and Accountability Plan for the Relocation and Resettlement of Residents within the Sanitation Protection Area of ‚Äã‚ÄãJiexiu City" („Ää‰ªã‰ºëÂ∏ÇÂç´ÁîüÈò≤Êä§Ë∑ùÁ¶ªÂÜÖÂ±ÖÊ∞ëÊê¨ËøÅÂÆâÁΩÆË¥£‰ªªÂàÜËß£ÂèäË¥£‰ªªËøΩÁ©∂ÊñπÊ°à„Äã). The local government of Yi'an Town became responsible for the relocation and resettlement and announced the following task plans: 1) On the basis of the preliminary investigation, combined with the actual situation and the will of the villagers, implement monetary compensation and transitional resettlement for residents of Liujiazhai Village that are severely polluted by Hong'an coking plant‚Äôs dust. 2) Establish the Liujiazhai Village Relocation and Resettlement Working Group and formulate a relocation plan with the guidance of the Yi'an Town government. The working group is expected to convene meetings for voting on relevant matters and make plans for the resettlement community or use existing affordable housing to carry out the resettlement for the whole Liujiazhai Village.[11]

In July 2018, there was another media report which disclosed that more than 10 migrant workers claimed that Hong‚Äôan Coking Technology had failed to pay the salary of the migrant.[12] The workers were hired by a company in Shandong Province to work on the coke oven tail gas desulfurization project at Hong‚Äôan Coking Technology between 2015-2016.[12]  The installation fee and the workers‚Äô salaries added up to CNY 4.23 million, which was still not paid in full after 3 years. The journalist from the media that received the migrant workers‚Äô complaint made futher investigation and also found environmental pollution related violations at the coking plant and called for further attention from the government authorities.[12]

In 2019, an anti-corruption legal case in Jinzhong City of Shanxi Province indicated that Antai Group paid bribery amounting to CNY 1.15 million to Qin Taiming, former vice chairman of Shanxi Jinzhong CPPCC, in return for environmental and operation permits between 2002 and 2013. While the details were not known, it corresponds to earlier reports in 2003-2004 regarding illegal land dispossesion by Antai in early years of its operation in Yi‚Äôan Town.[13][14]

The question raised by the journalist in 2017 was further uncovered in a media report in July 2020 after Jiexiu received the ecological and environmental inspection by the provincial government representatives. According to the report, Jiexiu City issued the "Rectification and Implementation Plan in response to the feedback from the Ecology and Environment Bureau of Shanxi Province" („ÄäË¥ØÂΩªËêΩÂÆûÂ±±Ë•øÁúÅÁîüÊÄÅÁéØÂ¢ÉÂéÖÁù£ÂØüÂèçÈ¶àÊÑèËßÅÊï¥ÊîπÊñπÊ°à„Äã) on 19 January 2020 based on the feedback from the environmental inspection team of Shanxi Province after unannounced site visits to Jiexiu. The implementation plan proposed to strictly inspect and investigate the environmental issues and accountability of corresponding entities and rectify within a restricted time frame. In June 2020, feedback from the local residents indicated that the highly polluting companies e.g. coal washing, coking and quarrying continued their business as usual even during the rectification period. According to local residents and workers, the local government was obviously involved in covering up the polluting behaviors and colluding with the polluting companies in face of the environmental inspection by higher level government authorities.[15]
