The state of Virginia has set itself the goal to achieve 3,000 megawatts (MW) of electricity generation by solar power. The Utah-based company called Sustainable Power Group (sPower) proposed the project Spotsylvania Solar Energy Center (SSEC) that has a planned rated capacity of 500 MW. [1],[2]

Step by step, solar energy production is settling at the East Coast of the U.S., where North Carolina is the largest provider of solar-based solar energy. The SSEC project shall be located east of the Rocky Mountains. Anyhow opinions on the project are conflictive ranging from viewing the project as a ‚Äúdangerous eyesore‚Äù [3] to a local economy boost. [3] The solar panels would cover around 3,500 acres (1416,4 hectares) making it the largest solar power project at the east coast. [4] The project site would encompass 6,350 acres (2569,8 hectares), of which at least 2,000 acres (809,4 hectares) shall be left undeveloped and conserved. [2]

The location proposal is Spotsylvania County (SSC) where 130,000 persons are residing at, is mainly famous for its Civil War history and agriculture. [1] The developing company sPower proposed in total three solar fields in the rural part SSC of Virginia where the largest would be constructed on land designated for agricultural use. [1] SSC is approximately 60 miles south of Washington D.C. [3]

 

Project involvement:

The Utah-based company Sustainable Power Group (sPower) proposed the SSEC project. [1] The 500MW-solar project is being developed, owned and operated by sPower, which itself is owned by a joint venture partnership between AES and AIMCo (Alberta Investment Management Cooperation) company [5] and was founded acquired in February, 2017 [2]. According to the SSEC project‚Äôs official website the construction could begin in March 2019 and last until December 2020. [2]

Microsoft contracted for 315 MW of the SSC project‚Äôs capacity, [6] for supplying two of its data centers that are located in Virginia that require ‚Äúmassive amounts of electricity‚Äù [4].

The company Microsoft is billing the 315 MW power of electricity with a power purchase agreement (PPA) from the two solar fields Pleinmont 1 and 2 that comprise over 750,000 solar photovoltaic (PV) modules. The scope of the PPA would make it the largest to date. Microsoft already had another 20 MW project in Virginia two years ago (2016). The software giant is financially involved as it tries to source its energy consumption by renewable energy and carbon offsetting. [7] By 2020 Microsoft wants to achieve 60% electricity generation by RE and is therefore investing into electricity generation projects in the field of renewable energy. [5] In a press release from December, 2018 sPower mentions other corporate off-takers for the electricity, which are: ‚ÄúMicrosoft, Apple, Akamai, Etsy and the University of Richmond.‚Äú [8] See also [1].

The electrical substation close-by is run by Dominion Energy.  The site in SSC was chosen also having a location where the solar electricity can be pumped into the grid system. [4]

 

Protest and resistance:

Residents from the surrounding area articulate the project to be more dangerous to the environment and surrounding towns than beneficial. Hence, the residents from Northern Virginia are protesting the proposed construction of the solar farm. [1]

According to an article published on NPR.org the heart of the protest is in a gated community named Fawn Lake. From here residents organized against the planned solar farm arguing that that they do not want to have such a massive project in the back of ‚Äòtheir‚Äô gated community. One resident from Fawn Lake stated that he is generally in favor of solar energy projects, but not right at the place where he lives. [3] In fact, according to the initial plans of sPower the northeastern corner of the solar field abut at two miles with Fawn Lake. [1]

An organizer of a group named Concerned Citizens of Spotsylvania said that the scale of the project has been wrong. He favors starting solar power plants in SSC, but just at a small scale.  Other protesters are worried about the solar project lowering the prices of their plots of land. [3] Some residents in SSC say that the installation of green technology is actually bad for the environment, claiming the loss of potential of trees reducing carbon dioxide. For the preparation of the solar project thousands of acres have already been chopped. [3]

The news channel Fox News published an article mentioning a resident blaming the company sPower to have chopped down the forest until 62 feet away from his two-story home. The same article also mentions houseowners selling their properties due to the planned SSEC project. [9]

The developing company replied that a vast amount of the neighbors will not be able to see PV power plant once it has been constructed and the cut-off forest areas for constructed will be afforested again. [3] When the local fight got the attention of the news channel Fox News, it stated that after the state‚Äôs approval it was up the county‚Äôs board of supervisors to take a decision, which at first hand did put off the voting. [3]

Another source mentions the meeting of a the Spotsylvania County Board of Supervisor that spent a night in early 2018 listening to testimonies for 9 hours. The high school auditorium during the testimony was packed with the two opposing groups wearing green (pro solar) and red (anti solar) shirts. [4] Prior to the testimony the community concerns were collected during a phase of eight months. [4]

 

One community concern was about sediment and erosion control, since another 200-acre solar farm in Essex County, Virginia got hit by a mudslide and eventually suffocated the nearby creeks and wetlands and was flowing down into the national wildlife refuge Rappahannock River. Another community concern expressed was the SSEC project making use of the municipal water line. [1]  While one concern clearly expressed was the one of Cadmium ‚Äì a chemical component in the solar PV panels ‚Äì to be a risk for public health, others were worries about the array being noisy, creating an island heat, causing brush fires or/and using up the local ground water. Moreover, the concerns of dropping plot value and restricted view for local residents were expressed. [10]

 

Consequence of protests:

Two out of three ‚Äòspecial-use permits applications‚Äô (SUPA) of the solar project have been recommended for denial. In consequence, the bid by the project developer sPower was in serious doubt. These two SUPAs account for 94% of the project‚Äôs planned area ‚Äì respectively 470 MW of rated capacity. [6]

The deadline for the vote by the Spotsylvania County Board of Supervisor on the SUPA to allow sPower to proceed with constructions on SSEC or not was January 2nd, 2019. During the eight prior months the plans for the three sites have been gone through an iterative process

County officials included a strict set of conditions to gain final approval. For instance, the utilization of cadmium telluride (CaTe) was prohibited in the project. Further, it was restricted for the project to just use public water. Moreover, a bond is allotted to ensure the site‚Äôs clean-up once the project is retiring as well as to keep distance in form of a ‚Äò350-foot setback from adjacent properties‚Äô. The recommended denial had over 500 votes against the project and was comprised mostly of people opposing the project. The final consensus finally synthesized in the size of the project being too big or ambitious. This is underlined by the fact that officials voted for the recommendation of other project approvals with the scope of a rated capacity of 30 MW, which was not heavily criticized but even supported by the local residents. [6]

Also the developer sPower acknowledged to maintain a safety buffer zone of at least 350 feet and cover the array with bushes and trees. [10]

Additionally, the water supply was switched to tapping into groundwater instead of using municipal water. Later, the company ensured that it will install tank water on its properties investing 3-5 US$ million.  [1] (Note that however according to an article found on Wtop, the company agreed to utilize municipal water and tweaked landscaping buffers. [11])

 

Status-Quo:

In December, 2018, sPower released the results of a poll conducted with 400 SSC‚Äôs voters. According to company‚Äôs release 67% of the population support the project and 77% do have favorable impression of solar energy usage. After this poll‚Äôs result it was considered likely Planning Commission would vote in favor of a recommendation of the project. [8]

After debating two years of debate the SSC Board of Supervisors voted for approval of the special-use permit of the U.S. East Coast‚Äôs largest power plant, thus deciding that the company sPower will build the project with 500 MW and costs of US million $615. [11]

On April 15, 2019 the company sPower released a document on SECC project‚Äôs webpage stating that it approved the special-use permit. Consequently, the project will be built in different phases during the next two years. [12]

Ahead of a community planning meeting the SECC‚Äôs company sPower articulated that they could do a US$ 25 million investment including the construction of a local park and a new fire station. Furthermore, sPower can imagine to donate solar arrays with the value of US$ 1 million to the community. [1]

 

Alternative Proposals:

No alternative proposals could be found.

other_types:
Airport

On January 8th 2019, the portuguese government signed an agreement with VINCI (now full shareholder of ANA ‚Äì Autoridade Nacional to significantly increase air traffic capacity in the two main Portuguese cities of Lisbon and Porto. The deal includes:

An expansion of the Portela Airport infrastructure in Lisbon which would increase possible air traffic by about 50%

An expansion of the Francisco S√° Carneiro Airport (Porto) which would lead to similar increase by about 60%

The building of an entirely new commercial airport in Montijo (southern bank of the Tejo) on top of the currently existing Air Force Base n¬∫ 6. This would also include the creation of new highway accesses to the airport and Vasco da Gama bridge (also owned by Vinci).

Not only would this lead to an enormous increase in air-traffic related CO2 emissions - the likes of which would make air-traffic the single largest cause of atmospheric polution in the country ‚Äì but the selected area is also one of the largest remaining wetland ecosystems in Europe, and a natural wildlife reserve crucial for dozens of bird species to feed in. The impact on local bird populations would be disastrous, to say nothing of the risk it constitutes for passenger safety to have birds flying at low altitudes near jet turbines.
As if this decision in itself wasn't bad enough, the conditions under which this deal was signed are in blantant disregard for EU laws pertaining to the need to perform an environmentl impact study prior to the construction of these projects. The preliminary study was completed in late July, and as we expected, it's findings are confusing to say the least: It warns of grave environmental and safety risks, but says the location is viable. The project is now in a period of public consultation until the 19th of September, though participation by the population has been predictably low; We also believe the choice of this period is not an accident either, as August and September are the months in which most of the population is on holidays and is less likely to notice or protest this governmental decision, which is plainly detrimental to public and ecological health and serves the capitalistic interests of those who would truly profit with this deal:the multinational corporation VINCI and certain members within the Portuguese political class.

<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify;line-height:115%"><span style="font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Arial",sans-serif" lang="EN-GB">Water
supply in the metropolitan area of Barcelona is historically owned and
organized by private, powerful actors (except for the civil war period 1936-1939).
A brief history overview shows the involvement of such entities: </span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom:0cm;text-align:justify;line-height:
115%;mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none"><span style="font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Arial",sans-serif" lang="EN-GB">The <i>Sociedad
General de Aguas de Barcelona </i>(SGAB) was established in the early 1920s due
to the purchase by a conglomerate by Spanish banks. SGAB is now owned by <i>AGBAR</i>
(<i>Aguas de Barcelona</i>) group which was created 1975. In 1979, <i>Lyonnaise
des Eaux </i>(later transformed into water multinational Suez)<i> </i>became a
main shareholder of the entity, now being the sole owner by buying all stocks
in 2015 [1]. Because the contracting conditions remained obscure throughout
many decades, in 2010, a judge ruled the situation of the company and its
activities to be illegal, forcing <i>AGBAR</i> and the Barcelona Metropolitan
Area (<i>AMB</i>) to sign a public-private partnership (PPP) contract in order
to regularise the situation [7]. 2012, a mixed-capital company was established (85%
private capital: <i>SGAB</i> holds 70% and another <span style="font-family:"Arial",sans-serif">15% belong to holding group <i>Criteria,
</i>part of the banc <i>La Caixa </i>[19]</span></span><span style="font-family:"Arial",sans-serif" lang="EN-GB">)</span><span style="font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Arial",sans-serif" lang="EN-GB">
meanwhile <i>AMB</i> holds only 15%). <i>Aig√ºes de Barcelona </i>now manages
and controls up to 93% of the urban water supply in the 23 municipalities and
thus 9 out of 10 customers depend on water supply by the <i>AGBAR</i> group. [1]
</span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom:0cm;text-align:justify;line-height:
115%;mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none"><span style="font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Arial",sans-serif" lang="EN-GB"> </span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify"><span style="font-size:12.0pt;line-height:107%;font-family:"Arial",sans-serif;
color:black;mso-themecolor:text1" lang="EN-GB">It was shown that this private management is
associated with low performance (</span><span style="font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:107%;font-family:"Arial",sans-serif" lang="EN-GB">leakages in the network are
30% greater and investment is 15.5% less than in the public sector) and that financially
the management of the private company results in relatively high costs of water
management (</span><span style="font-size:12.0pt;line-height:107%;
font-family:"Arial",sans-serif;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
mso-fareast-language:DE" lang="EN-GB">high levies and fees charged by the</span><span style="font-size:12.0pt;line-height:107%;font-family:"Arial",sans-serif" lang="EN-GB">
</span><span style="font-size:12.0pt;line-height:107%;font-family:
"Arial",sans-serif;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-fareast-language:
DE" lang="EN-GB">administrations in exchange for privatising the service, exorbitant
salaries for the administrative councils and financial spending not associated
with water delivery). As a result, more than half of the water bill in
Barcelona is filled with unnecessary or illegitimate costs which are not
related to water services [25]</span><span style="font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:107%;font-family:"Arial",sans-serif" lang="EN-GB">. <span style="color:black;
mso-themecolor:text1"></span></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom:0cm;text-align:justify;line-height:
115%;mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none"><span style="font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Arial",sans-serif" lang="EN-GB">Further
estimates revealed that <i>AGBARs</i> water rates are more expensive than in
neighbouring towns with public management such as El Prat de Llobregat and
Barbera. As a result, a part of the costs is financed at the expense of
consumers through taxes included in the water bills. <span class="etext">This
part of the bill represents approximately 3% of mean family budgets and
eventually build a greater proportion of the bill than the service itself. This
development can affect lower income households of the central city and
surrounding towns relatively more [2]. </span>In the Spanish context this is a
severe condition since 17% of the population suffer from energy poverty,
meaning frequent difficulties of paying their electricity, gas or water bill
[8]. In Barcelona over 120,000 people have been found to be suffering from this
specific kind of poverty related to access to water. These cases of water cut-offs
mostly occur where water services are privately managed: 75% of municipalities
with private services cut off water supplies for unpaid bills, whereas in the
municipalities where the service is public that proportion falls to only 8%
[25].</span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom:0cm;text-align:justify;line-height:
115%;mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none"><span style="font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Arial",sans-serif" lang="EN-GB"> </span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify"><span style="font-size:12.0pt;line-height:107%;font-family:"Arial",sans-serif" lang="EN-GB">Civil
society activists in Barcelona close to the NGO <i>Enginyeria sense Fronteres (Engineers
without Borders)</i> and the <i>Federation of Neighbourhood Associations of
Barcelona (FAVB)</i> <span style="color:black;mso-themecolor:text1">are </span>challenging
this private management and fight for public water in Barcelona. Therefore,
they <span style="color:black;mso-themecolor:text1">established the Plataforma <i>Aigua
es Vida</i> in 2011 (Water is life platform) [11]. The platform was built by a
wide variety of civil society organisations: neighbourhood associations, trade
unions, environmental and international solidarity organisations. Its aim is to
advocate for the public sector to decide on water policy and control the entire
water cycle in Barcelona and all of Catalonia, including civil society
participation and oversight to ensure the quality of the service and democratic
governance. The platform is actively campaigning against the role of the
private sector in the management of water and sanitation and especially the
monopoly position that <i>AGBAR</i> holds [10]. </span></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom:0cm;text-align:justify;line-height:
115%;mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none"><span style="font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Arial",sans-serif" lang="EN-GB">The 35-year
integral water cycle concession for greater Barcelona to the largest private
operator without an open tender is facing concerted opposition from competing
private sector water operators (<i>Aguas de Valencia</i>) as well as NGOs and
associations. Critics are based on the lack of transparency, missing auditing
by external actors of asset distributions as well as the precarious legal
position of the operations themselves [3]. In March 2016, a judgment of the Court
of Justice of Catalonia (TSJC) cancelled the public-private partnership
contract for water supply to 23 municipalities in the Metropolitan Area of
Barcelona, arguing that there is neither a legal base, economic reasoning or
technical base for the companies activities [15]. <i>AGBAR</i> has filed an
appeal with the Supreme Court of Spain to override the ruling [7]. Continuously,
the court ruling by the TSJC passed to the Supreme Court of Spain, which has
the obligation of reaching a final verdict for the case [9].</span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom:0cm;text-align:justify;line-height:
115%;mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none"><span style="font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Arial",sans-serif" lang="EN-GB"> </span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom:0cm;text-align:justify;line-height:
115%;mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none"><span style="font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Arial",sans-serif" lang="EN-GB">As the
result of years of citizen movement campaigning for access to basic rights and
against the corruption of traditional political parties the election in 2015
brought the political group <i>Barcelona en Com√∫</i> into Barcelonas City Council
[7]. The group incorporated among leftist parties such as Podemos (resulting
partly from the anti-austerity movement), also parts of the above-mentioned
civil campaigns and implemented remunicipalisation demands into their agenda.
Said agenda specifically aims to establish democratic and transparent
assessment, debate and decision structures regarding preferred public interest
while also involving workers unions [4]. </span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom:0cm;text-align:justify;line-height:
115%;mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none"><span style="font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Arial",sans-serif" lang="EN-GB"> </span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom:0cm;text-align:justify;line-height:
115%;mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none"><span style="font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Arial",sans-serif" lang="EN-GB">Political
contestation by <i>Barcelona En Comu</i> started with a motion in 2016 to analyse
and concentrate on direct public management of the water cycle. Subsequently,
most leftist groups of the Barcelona City Council voted in favour [14]. This
process can be seen as an important step forward towards establishing an agenda
to remunicipalise water services in the metropolitan area. <i>AGBAR</i> took a
counter position to the plan and decided not to co-operate and did not provided
any corporate or technical information. [7] </span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom:0cm;text-align:justify;line-height:
115%;mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none"><span style="font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Arial",sans-serif" lang="EN-GB"> </span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom:0cm;text-align:justify;line-height:
115%;mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none"><span style="font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Arial",sans-serif;
color:black;mso-themecolor:text1" lang="EN-GB">In 2018 more than 200 citizen organisations
initiated the Public and Democratic Water Movement to guarantee public,
democratic water management in the Metropolitan Area of Barcelona [23]. The
Movement soon started a petition and collected more than 25,000 signatures
showing a more than sufficient number of voices supporting a referendum on
water management in Barcelona. The petition proposed the following question to
citizens: "Do you wish water management in Barcelona to be public and with
citizen participation?". <i>AGBAR</i> started several legal and
administrative appeals and leveraged all its connections in the economic and
political establishments to prevent the referendum from taking place [6]. Also,
the company launched a huge marketing operation including advertising space on local
TV, radio and billboards and sponsoring community initiatives in order to
improve its image [8]. Initially, the local law allowing such public
consultations fell short of the necessary support in the plenary session held
by the Barcelona Council in April 2018. Effectively this was due to formal
issues regarding the nature of the motion <i>Barcelona en Comu </i>started not
of the content itself [12]. However, the local referendum on remunicipalisation
of water was postponed to the next electoral cycle [6]. Despite losing
percentage points, <i>Barcelona en Comu</i> managed to win the 2019 election
and built a government with the </span><span style="font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Arial",sans-serif" lang="EN-GB">Socialists' Party of Catalonia
[24] which brings new opportunities to focus on remunicipalisation in the
following years.</span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom:0cm;text-align:justify;line-height:
115%;mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none"><span style="font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Arial",sans-serif;
color:black;mso-themecolor:text1" lang="EN-GB"> </span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom:0cm;text-align:justify;line-height:
115%;mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none"><span style="font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Arial",sans-serif;
color:black;mso-themecolor:text1" lang="EN-GB">In 2019 judges voted in favour of <i>AGBAR</i>,
legitimizing the legal status of the mixed capital company. Additionally, the
court stressed that <i>AGBAR</i>s investment in another 500km canalisation
system would mean a compensation in case of a potential remunicipalisation.
Following the highest Spanish court, the TSCJ cannot be seen as a legal base
for expropriation but does also not exclude this option. In Summary, it can
serve as a basis for the application of the preceptors of exception (to the
publicity of the procedure of awarding and free competition) [15]</span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom:0cm;text-align:justify;line-height:
115%;mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none"><span style="font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Arial",sans-serif;
color:red" lang="EN-GB"> </span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom:0cm;text-align:justify;line-height:
115%;mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none"><span style="font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Arial",sans-serif;
color:black;mso-themecolor:text1" lang="EN-GB">In 2020 <i>SUEZ</i> announced plans to sell
major parts <i>AGBAR</i> assets in Spain despite overall unclear market
conditions, reluctant investors as well as its rather stable economic situation
of income revenues in times of crisis due to the Covid-19 pandemic (public
concessions with local governments and permanent water demand by citizens)
[18]. Reasons of this disinvestment strategy for the following years can be
seen in a general plan to reduce the company‚Äôs debt and to take financial
advantages of a short-term selling process based on the stability and
investment attractivity <i>AGBAR</i> offers [20]. </span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom:0cm;text-align:justify;line-height:
115%;mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none"><span style="font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Arial",sans-serif;
color:black;mso-themecolor:text1" lang="EN-GB"> </span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom:0cm;text-align:justify;line-height:
115%;mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none"><i><span style="font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Arial",sans-serif;
color:black;mso-themecolor:text1" lang="EN-GB">Aigua es Vida</span></i><span style="font-size:12.0pt;line-height:115%;font-family:"Arial",sans-serif;
color:black;mso-themecolor:text1" lang="EN-GB"> on the one hand claims that <i>AGBAR</i>
increases tariffs to create a higher value of the company before selling it on
international markets despite the difficult situation for many customers. On
the other hand, <i>Aigua es Vida</i> is pushing the <i>AMB</i> to urgently
prevent the company from taking advantage of the crisis and stresses that the
situation showed the necessity to employ all resources towards the
remunicipalisation of </span><span style="font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:115%;font-family:"Arial",sans-serif" lang="EN-GB">water. Therefore, the platform
appeals to the <i>AMB</i> to reduce tariffs and the city council to actively
address the unjust decision of the Spanish Supreme Court that is incompatible
with the desire 80% of the metropolitan population [21]. In the face of the
Covid-19 crisis and the hygiene and sanitation crisis these actors also reached
out against national lobby groups of powerful water companies and demand the Spanish
state and government officials via the <i>Red Agua P√∫blica (RAP)</i> to
acknowledge the human right to water and to implement a sustainable,
transparent and democratic water supply system. They invoke national Law 8 and
11 of March 2020 <span style="mso-spacerun:yes"> </span>which guarantee
the<span style="mso-spacerun:yes">  </span>human right to water for vulnerable
social sectors or people with risk of social exclusion (RD law 8/2020), as well
as those who, due to the COVID-19 crisis and its consequences, are potentially
vulnerable (RD law 11/2020). [22]</span></p>

<p></p>

  <w:LsdException Locked="false" SemiHidden="true" UnhideWhenUsed="true"

<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify;line-height:150%"><span style="font-size:12.0pt;line-height:150%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;
color:black;mso-themecolor:text1">A pesar de los trabajos de limpieza que se
han realizado tanto la Secretar√≠a de Medio Ambiente (Sedema) y La Comisi√≥n de
Recursos Naturales y Desarrollo Rural (Corenadr) en lo que va de este 2022.<sub>
[1] </sub>no has sido suficiente para la zona Lacustre de Xochimilco presenta
contaminaci√≥n que se ha venido generando por asentamientos de la mancha urbana
que al paso de los a√±os no se ha podido controlar, la descarga de los desechos domiciliarios,
la invasi√≥n de terrenos con residuos de cascajo y basura, basura que genera
plagas de diferentes tipos. Este conflicto ambiental expone a las personas a
diferentes enfermedades a causa de la contaminaci√≥n de la zona Lacustre.</span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify;line-height:150%"><sub><span style="font-size:12.0pt;line-height:150%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;
color:black"><span style="mso-spacerun:yes"> </span></span></sub><span style="font-size:12.0pt;line-height:150%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif">La
extracci√≥n de agua es otro de los conflictos que se hace presente, con el fin
de subsanar la falta de agua potable tanto en la zona como en la Ciudad de
M√©xico, esto ha provocado que los canales de esta zona se modifiquen, generando
grietas y en ocasiones hoyos, convirti√©ndose en socavones como el que apareci√≥
a principios de enero en el 2017.<sub><span style="color:black"> [2]</span></sub></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify;line-height:150%"><span style="font-size:12.0pt;line-height:150%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;
color:black;mso-themecolor:text1">Aunado a esto la planta tratadora de aguas
del Cerro de la Estrella responsable de suministra gran parte del agua que va a
la zona chinampera y los canales de Xochimilco, se encuentra en riesgo de
desaparecer. ‚ÄúLo anterior, debido a que la infraestructura es demasiado vieja y
se ha convertido en gran parte en obsoleta‚Äù.<span class="d2edcug0">‚Äù</span><sub>
[</sub></span><sub><span style="font-size:12.0pt;line-height:150%;font-family:
"Times New Roman",serif">3] </span></sub><span style="font-size:12.0pt;
line-height:150%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif">Im√°genes de la 13 a la 16
de la PTAR. Del Cerro de la Estrella.</span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify;line-height:150%"><span class="d2edcug0"><span style="font-size:12.0pt;line-height:150%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif">‚ÄúLa
zona lacustre de Xochimilco depende de manera casi total de las aportaciones de
agua tratada, principalmente de la P.T.A.R: ‚ÄúCerro de la Estrella‚Äù, la
suspensi√≥n de sus aportaciones generar√° un efecto adverso en el ecosistema, ya
que las especies end√©micas de la zona se quedar√°n sin el h√°bitat que les
proporciona el agua tratada que circula por los canales. Adem√°s, la zona
lacustre de Xochimilco cumple una funci√≥n importante en el microclima de la
Ciudad de M√©xico, regulando la temperatura en las temporadas de calor y fr√≠o‚Äù</span></span><span style="font-size:12.0pt;line-height:150%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif">.<sub><span style="color:black"> [4]</span></sub></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify;line-height:150%"><span style="font-size:12.0pt;line-height:150%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif">‚ÄúLos
canales con mejores niveles de agua se concentran en las zonas tur√≠sticas de
Xochimilco ‚Äîlamenta‚Äî, mientras que el abasto de agua y la rehabilitaci√≥n de los
canales de las zonas de cultivo no son considerados tan prioritarios‚Äù. Por eso,
las personas chinamperas reman con miedo a encallar y se ven obligadas a buscar
alternativas por cuenta propia, como el dragado de canales, para impedir que el
desecamiento siga afectando a sus chinampas y la producci√≥n.</span><b><sub><span style="font-size:12.0pt;line-height:150%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-fareast-language:ES-MX"> [5]</span></sub></b><span class="d2edcug0"><span style="font-size:12.0pt;line-height:150%;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif"></span></span></p>

<p style="text-align:justify;line-height:150%"><span style="color:black">Testimonio
de Chinamperos argumentan que el problema de la contaminaci√≥n se ha venido
agravando por los asentamientos de la misma gente que va creciendo en la zona,
esta contaminaci√≥n no solo es por los residuos s√≥lidos, de modo que los olores tambi√©n
se hacen presente en la zona.</span></p>

<p style="text-align:justify;line-height:150%"><span style="color:black">En
2010</span><span class="d2edcug0"> la </span>de la Procuradur√≠a Ambiental y del
Ordenamiento Territorial (PAOT), argumento que parte de los asentamientos ‚Äúpermite
la recarga de acu√≠feros, biodiversidad, conservaci√≥n del habitad y es el inicio
de corredores biol√≥gicos,‚Äù <sub><span style="color:black">[6]</span></sub></p>

<p style="text-align:justify;line-height:150%"><span style="color:black">Sin embargo,
la recarga de este tipo de aguas en la zona provoca la reproducci√≥n de
microrganismos que afecta la salud de las personas, debido a que las aguas
contienen materia fecal tanto de humanos como de animales, no siendo apta para
el riego.<sub> [7]</sub> <span style="mso-spacerun:yes"> </span></span></p>
